header.indicatorTitle: Fisheries-independent Survey-based Indices of Forage Fishes in the Gulf of Alaska
header.authorAffiliations: Resource Assessment and Conservation Engineering Division, Alaska Fisheries Science Center, NOAA Fisheries

body.indicatorDescription:
Forage fish are key prey for a variety of groundfish, as well as seabirds and marine mammals. As a result, changes in forage fish abundance and body condition can affect the productivity of higher-trophic level consumers (e.g., [@sigler_seasonal_2007], [@piatt_extreme_2020], [@robinson_reduction_2024]). Individual species of forage fish respond differently to environmental conditions (e.g., [@gorman_spatial_2018], [@robards_growth_2002]). The North Pacific Fishery Management Council has identified several forage fish species or groups of species for federal management. This indicator consists of data from seven forage groups: Pacific herring (_Clupea pallasii_), Pacific capelin (_Mallotus catervarius_ or _Mallotus villosus_), eulachon (_Thaleichthys pacificus_), sand lance (_Ammodytes_ spp.), Myctophids (family Myctophidae), Pacific sandfish (_Trichodon trichodon_), and pricklebacks (family Stichaeidae). Among these taxa, Pacific herring and eulachon are the most dominant according to bottom trawl survey data, followed by capelin and sandfish.
Since 1990, the RACE Groundfish Assessment Program (GAP) has conducted annual fishery-independent summer bottom trawl surveys in the GOA using standardized trawl gear and methods. Though catchability is low for small forage species in this survey, it has not changed over time, so biomass index trends from GAP surveys are likely to reflect changes in the abundance of species and life history stages that are available to the survey, especially if trends are sustained over time.
Regional and subarea (NMFS statistical areas 610, 620, 630, 640, 650) indices of abundance (biomass in kilotons) and confidence intervals were estimated for each taxonomic group by fitting a multivariate random effects model (REM) to subarea design-based index of abundance time series that were calculated from RACE Groundfish Assessment Program (GAP) summer bottom trawl survey catch and effort data. Indices were calculated for the entire standardized survey time series (1990 to 2025). Design-based indices of abundance were calculated using the gapindex R package [@gapindex] and REM were fitted to the time series using the rema R package [@rema]. Code and data used to produce these indicators are provided in the _esrindex_ R package and repository [@esrindex].

body.statusAndTrends:
Several forage fish sampled by the bottom trawl survey in 2025 showed an increased estimated abundance compare to the previous year. The estimated biomass of forage species in the GOA were above 1SD for herring, and at or below -1SD for Pacific sandfish and myctophids (Figure 1). Sand lance, myctophids, eulachon, and herring all showed increases compared to 2023. Biomass indices declined between 2023 and 2025 for capelin, sandfish, and pricklebacks (Figure 1).
Eulachon have been most prevalent in the Yakutat survey district though their largest biomass has historically occurred in the Kodiak district. Biomass in the Kodiak district appears to be continuing to increase in recent surveys after highs recorded between 2000 and 2015 (Figure 2). Eulachon biomass has also continued to increase in the Southeast OUtside region (650).
Capelin biomass has historically been highest in the Kodiak district. Their biomass according to the bottom trawl survey has been declining since 2021, and despite anticipated increases in capelin abundance baesd on winter acoustic surveys, they cotninued to decline in 2025.
Sandfish, prickelbacks, and sand lance are uniformly uncommon in trawl catches across the GOA survey years and districts, though there are episodic years with large biomass estimates for these species over the survey history.
body.factorsInfluencingTrends: , In the GOA, herring and sand lance have been observed to positively respond to warm environmental conditions, while capelin increase during cooler periods (McGowan et al. 2019). Herring, as monitored in Southeast Alaska and Prince William Sound had strong year classes in 2016 and 2020. Those trends are reflected in these trawl data and show GOA-wide increases including in the Kodiak and West Yakutat regions.
body.implications: Recent increases in herring biomass may indicate more availability of forage for humpback whales and other known herring predators.

Panels show showing the observed survey biomass index mean (blue points), random effects model fitted mean (solid black line), 95% confidence interval (gray shading), overall time series mean (solid gray line), and horizontal dashed gray lines representing one standard deviation from the mean.
